titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 12. VI:30. Monday— Wise’s Resolution upon M. L. Davis’s charge against a member of Congress, debated the whole day— Waddy Thompsons motion to reconsider the Bill passed on Saturday for relief of the Heirs of R. Fulton.
13. VI. Tuesday— Both the children and Elizabeth sick— John H. Pennington, and his project for navigating through the air.

H.R.US— Wise reads from a Newark Newspaper. F. O. J. Smith moves to lay on the table—lost— Much debate Matthew L. Davis summoned to the bar—objects to the first interrogatory, and withdraws—two hours debate whether he shall be heard—determined 103 to 90 that he shall— He refuses to answer the question whether he wrote the Spy’s Letter— Answers the 2d and 3d. The accused not a member of the house— Davis discharged and the House adjourn 1/4 past 4. Rainy day. Took G Kemble home

14. IV. Wednesday— Connell John from Philadelphia— H.R.U.S—reading of the Journal Wise proposes to amend, by inserting the Oath administered to M. L Davis— To tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth touching the matter in question before the house— Boon moves to strike out from the Journal Davis’s written protest against the interrogatory whether he was the author of the Spy in Washington. flinching debate, motion to strike out laid on the table by yeas and nays 103 to 79.— Henry moves to suspend the rules to call the States for Petitions—carried— I presented 350. many others presented. States called through. Adjourned about 6. O’Clock— The Children and Elizabeth sick.

15. V. Thursday— Elizabeth and both the children confined to their beds with catarrhal fevers— Comee. of Manufactures, present Adams, Foster, Slade, Vail, Webster—Absent Biddle Hunter, Naylor, Tillinghast— Read Memorial of William Jackson, and others for repeal of duties on Olive Oil, and Tallow— Voted to lay on the table all the applications for repeal of existing duties, or levying of new ones— House in Session— Bill relating to Commissioners for reservations in a Choctaw Treaty— Bell, Dawson, Crary, Parker, Lyon, No Quorum—adjourned, soon after 3. Raw cold— Snow.

16. V:30. Friday— The meazles broke out thick last Night with the meazles, and are distressingly ill— H.R.U.S. Howard produced Letters from Officers on the Canadian frontier to the Secy of War, and moved to suspend the rules, to take up the Bill to amend the Act of 1818 for preserving neutrality. The motion was carried without opposition. The Bill from the Senate was debated til half past 3 when the House adjourned— I rode in a Hack to the Capitol and home in my own Carriage though the Streets were a glare of ice— Rain Snow, hail a dark day clearing off with a cold gale at Sunset— Took Patterson of New-York, and Ogden Hoffman to their lodgings— Joseph C Lovejoy brought me a Letter from Lewis Tappan—and spent 2 hours of the Evening here— Asked me to write a preface to the Memoir of his brother— The children both very ill

17. V:30. Saturday— Fahrenheit 14— Mrs Adams up all Night with the children— F. Sumter with Letter from his father Dr Huntt— War Office Poinsett— Left James Collier of Cohassett’s Letter with him H.R.U.S.— Reports of Committees— Canada Bill debated Samson Mason, Holsey, Howard, Bynum Elisha Whittlesey— Various amendments— Mine inter alia— Horace Everett’s Bill and Amendments to be printed— Mr Smith a
Surgeon General of the Army of Texas, sent to call me out of my Seat, and introduced himself to me—said his grandfather’s name was Abel Adams—went from Connecticut to North-Carolina— That he himself was educated at Yale College—had been in Europe and lived in North Carolina, till the last two years which he has passed in Texas— Wishes the annexation of Texas to the United States which he shall always consider his home &c— I walked home from the Capitol—glare of ice.

18. VI. Sunday— Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Gurley, from Luke 18.29.30— Mr Fowler present but unwell—notice that there would be no service there this afternoon— Collection next Sunday for the domestic missions. Glass Streets— Afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read Prayers for Sexagesima Sunday and preached from Hosea 10.12— Fahrenheit this morning 17.

19. VI:30. Monday— Tyler. Benjamin O. wants to borrow 100. his wife’s Letter.— H.R.US— Motions to suspend the rules to take up the Canada bills—not carriedto 56.— The States called, for Resolutions— I offered four concerning our Relations with Mexico—and one to require the production of Credentials by every member before taking his seat in the house— Howard moved to refer the Series to the Committee of Foreign Affairs, to which I objected, and he objected to the single Resolution, on the ground that we could not act for the next house— All my Resolutions lie over one day— Adjourned soon after 3. Senate Chamber— Clay on the sub-treasury and agt. Calhoun. Joseph C Lovejoy in the Evening—returned his papers. Letter from Charles—has a son, born the 16th. 9. A.M.

20 V. Tuesday— Thomas Sammons an old revolutionary soldier’s agent was here, talking two hours about his agency, and revolutionary claims at the Pension Office. H.R.U S—the Committee of foreign Affairs instead of reporting upon the Bill and amendments referred to them yesterday, asked to be discharged from further consideration of them, and reported back three or four
new amendments, upon which a new debate consumed the day—Patton—Loomis, Smith of Maine, Whittlesey, Legare Pickens, and Menefee took part in this debate— I took part in it myself— Wise moved—reference of the Bill as now amended to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union but failed— The bill and amendments as now before the House are to be printed. My resolution calling for the Gorostiza pamphlet was adopted— I withdrew the part of the Resolution which called for the name of the diplomatic functionary who furnished the Secretary of State with the pamphlet— I walked to and from the Capitol— Walk to and from the Capitol— Met Dr Francis Parkman— Letter to my Son.

21. VI:30— Wednesday— Fahrenheit 10. after Sunrise— H.RU.S The Canada Bill resumed, and discussed—from 1 till 5. O’Clock Howard, Loomis Holsey, Cambreleng, myself Legare, W. Thomson— A. H. Everett presents a new amendment— Bill to be reprinted with all the amendments— I answered Holsey Cambreleng and Toucey— Walk to and from the Capitol— Mr Pettrich here with two drawings of designs for an equestrian Statue of Genl. Washington— Mr J. Payne Todd . . . was here towards the close of the Evening.

22. VI:30. Thursday.— Committee of Manufactures— Meeting day— Naylor and Slade the only members who attended except myself who attended.— Nothing done— H.R.U.S. in Session— Bill for authorizing a judicial trial of the Maison rouge & Bastrop land claims debated till the expiration of the hour— Canada Bill debated till past 4. O’Clock— Underwood, Bell, Mercer, Everett Patton— Squabble between Mercer and me about Genet’s land commissions at Charleston S.C— Library— New Annual Register for 1793.— Everett’s amendment proposed Toucey’s Speech— Wise— Walk to and from the Capitol. Robertson’s proposed amendment— Dr Francis Parkman here, but I did not see him— Thomas ill.

23. V:15. Friday— Fahrenheit 15— At Pension-Office—left with the Commissioner, the widowpapers for a pension-claim— Bank of Washington— Patent Office— H. L. Ellsworth left 15 dollars in silver with Mr Hand for Lewis Kenney— H.R.U.S. Rule suspended and the use of the Hall granted for the Congressional Temperance Society— Canada Bill— Bandied from Pillar to post—Patton, Robertson, Dunn Howard M. Fillmore and Marvin, each one having some amendment of his own. Mercer renews the question about Genet’s land Commissions at Charleston— My answer— Drowsy evening.
24. VI. Saturday. Fahrenheit Morning 30.

H.R.U.S. thin house— Graves and Cilley gone out to fight a duel—with rifles at 80 paces— Lawler of Alabama presented Resolutions for the annexation of Texas— Speaker decides they are not within the Resolution of 21. Decr. Potts objects, and the Resolutions lie over. W. Cost Johnson Resolution for a Committee of enquiry concerning the public Lands— Canada Bill— T. T. Whittlesey, James Garland, Crockett—Toucey Petrikin moves the previous question carried,—Bill rejected 88 to 76— Patton moves a reconsideration, carried— Motion to refer the bill to the Committee on the judiciary—lost— Bill referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs— Adjourned after 4.— Met Joseph Blunt— Walk home.— My wife much indisposed— Cilley killed in the duel— Letter from Charles.

25. VI:30. Sunday— My wife quite ill, all night and confined to her bed all this day— W. S. Smith here— At the Capitol, heard Mr Slicer, the Chaplain of the House from Luke 14.18. Notices the duel, both in prayer and Sermon— Conversation with Howard and E. Whittlesey— Call on C. Cushing, confined to his chamber—has been by a relapse of bilious fever 9 days to his bed— Letter fromAlvord, Chairman of Comee. of Massachusetts Legislature to the Delegation— Afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley— Prayers for Quinquegesima Sunday— Sermon from Job 31.14. Notice of Service on Ash Wednesday, and Communion next Sunday, first in lent— Dissipation and agitation of mind—finished a careless preface for the Memoir of the life of E. P. Lovejoy.

26. VI.30. Monday— Fahrenheit— 17— H.R.U.S.— Amasa J. Parker andM’lelland, propose to expel the duelists. Fairfield announces the death of Cilley in the usual way. Funeral tomorrow— Letter from R. R. Gurley, House adjourn immediately— Meeting of Massachusetts delegation— Letter from J. C. Alvord, Chairman of a joint Committee of the

Massachusetts Legislature discussed— I was charged nolens volence to draft an answer.— Cary in the Evening.
Naval depot at Brunswick Georgia— Rival to Charleston S.C— Calhoun influence.

27. V:30. Tuesday— Fahrenheit 17.— H.R.U.S— Funeral of Jonathan Cilley— Prayer bySlicer chaplain of the Senate— Sermon bychaplain of the house— Walk with J. Payne Todd to the Capitol— Rode with G. Kemble, James Garland and Elisha Haley to the grave-yard—back without Garland— Clerk’s Office. Printed Journal. Resolutions of Masstts. Legislature of 12 April 1837. walk home— My wife up, but yet much indisposed— Evening at the Capitol of the Congressional temperance Society— F. Grundy presiding—Marsh—Randolph—Briggs— Mr Buckingham the Englishman—discourse of an hour and a half— Amusing and eloquent— Borden—Whittlesey— Hall crowded— Not many members of Congress— Shrove Tuesday—
28. VI.30 Wednesday— Fahrenheit 18.

Alexr. H. Everett— H.R.U.S. Fairfield offers a Resolution to appoint a Committee of 7. to enquire into the causes of Cilley’s death—debate—W. Cost Johnson Parker—Dawson Potter, W.Garland of Louisiana—Evans, Loomis, M. Morris—Jenifer—Bell— Motions for delay— Clowney moves previous question—carried. Resolution adopted. Morris’s instruction to the Comee. to report a Bill against dueling—carried— Jenifer’s motion discussed, but no question taken— Adjourned at 4— My wife still confined—
